titleStmt.title: M1-8, 2 of 10. Anon. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 78-102. 13p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8. 2 of 8. Anon. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 78-102. 13p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

del.l: Anon died .. round about 1477. It was the
printed book that killed him yet at fair, the printed

p.l: Then the house is built; & the some one – a clergyman;
looks back. He looks back Time has drawn its blue veil
over the horizon. He has time to think about the
past in the quiet of the parsonage. He
Anon is singing
all Knigh
Then at When the house is built, Anon stops at the
back door. He sings Upstairs they talk French; English
has was gone down into the kitchen into the farmyard.
He sings in an uncouth fou . . He sings to young men &
maids. He tells them what they have heard already.
But save for this voice the English might be a dumb race.
& for the voice of Chaucer & Langland the English
might be a dumb race; to
Then The pr Then about
Anon is still the only articulate voice.
The house however became more &
more comfortable. At last we see someone in the house

winter is past. . . And the great
Ethn Elizabethan house is
in existence.
The Printing Press had come. It is the Printing
Press that preserves the dumb world.
Then when the house was built, & roads led often
flooded, often deep in mud, led to from house to house
Anon came along the roads, came the minstrels, the
jugglers, the singers, bear leaders, singing their crude
songs at the back door, to the farm hands & the
maid servants, in the uncouth jargon of the their native tongue
Upstairs they spoke French. The nature singer was
man at the back door was despised. He [It?] had no
name, no station yet even the Kings & Queens

nameless. His songs were unwritten
he was ribald, he was often obscene. It is Anon
During the silent centuries, before the book was printed,
his is the only voice that was to be heard in

It was the Yet, during all these centuries,

Of the writer [nothing?] is known. Malory is

Caxton [dow?] his [loubell?] the end of that

After that, we have the individual; the man

There is Harrison in [Essex?], the [parsonage?] in

the preacher, the man who went from town to

quote.l: found the church door fast locked
and one of the parish came to me &
Lo this is a busy day with us, we cannot
hear you, it is Robin Hood's day. The
parish are far abroad to gather for
Robin hood,... I was fain there to give

place to R H: I thought my [Racket?]
wd. would
have been regarded, tho' I was not; but it
wd would not serve, it was fain to give place to
Robin hoods men. It was no laughing matter
my friends, it is a weeping matter, a heavy
matter, a heavy matter, ....

del.l: It is the preacher who shows us the
living body of the living body the English peasant whose
still honouring the pagan Gods: still
honouring the old gods; still immersed in
superstition. The preacher [imposes upon them his?]
God. It is in the preacher who
killed There is the voice that went
up & down England Latimer was no
chronicler of times past. To Latimer the old

p.l: going up & down England, saw the peasant as he
is now at this moment, in King Edward Sixths
reign in 1549. He saw the peasant
still harbouring old superstitions, going on
pilgrimage, setting up candles, worshipping
[pigs?] bones. The saw He saw the There was
no beauty, it was but only superstition &
corruption in their ancient games. He
saw the present moment in all its crudity. He
saw the was no antiquary. He knew what he
He had his His eyes were open as he rode from
town to town to what was actually in existence.
He saw poverty; he saw the peasant suff
unable to buy a grave. He saw the nobles
[eye?] long the field. He saw the great man lying
[illeg.] to in bed, after his [hawking?] & his hunting, in the
poor made waiting hour after hour to bring his
care upon him. He saw the great ladies
wearing vardigalls & puffing their hair out in
tussocks. And what he saw in the
roads, in the fields, in the house, he
described in a voice that stumbles & stutters &
cannot keep to the theme; for he is
enraged by what he sees. This was the voice of
the new learning. As he walked in the
A of C. Archbishop of Canterbury's garden, looking in my [bokes?] –

l.quote: "I cannot go long [bokes?], for poor folks
come unto me, desiring tha me that I will
[illeg.] so that their matters may be heard

faithfully, [outpoured?] not [illeg.] he
wd would
he brings before the young king the state of

To him the old Engand is no less It is the
preacher who [exacts?] the farmers farmers; the
for he fain upon them the light of the new
knowledge. He alone knows what he
is saying for he too, until he was thirty

p.l: It was master Bilney at Cambridge who opened his eyes.
Master Bilney who went about among the poor &
the sick, & finally had a paper set in his hand &
was burnt. So, it was he, he the [illeg.] will be
burnt. Meanwhile he will speak the truth; he
will speak in English. He will speak in a
word that the poor, the [simple?] can
understand, in their own tongue. It was
the preacher then, saying the Lords Prayer in to

at the
beg beginning & the end of his [sermons?] who
put English into the highest places.
But indeed while during all [minstrels?] &
mummers, he was yet fashioning a
language for them to use. He was
giving a common tongue speech for nobles &
peasants. But to He Just as
Harrison comes Standing on the edge of the edge of the
Ethn Elizabethan age, he saw the [gorgeous?] buildings she
and Harrison saw there. He deplored them
Never has there been such building & planting" he
saw. Never had there been such
crime, such splendour, such poverty.

but great mens rooms in colleges.
It will come to pass that we shall
have nothing but a little English divinity
that will bring the realm into a very
barbarousness, & utter decay of
learning. Give the money "that it
were wont to bestow in pilgrimage
matters, in trentalls, in masses, in
purgatory matters" to poor [illeg.]
so that they may become scholars.

p.l: This is the voice that ousted superstition: the voice of
reason, of common sense. By using English, by
putting English in the pulpit the preacher was
forging the very weapon that gave the
old [methods?] a new lease of life.
Thus Harrison and Latimer both saw what we can
still see, the great Elizabethan house
sitting often on the ruins & foundation of the old.
The sight & sound in both of them the same
denunciation: Harrison [described?] the men,
with him . . Latimer the women
But We sti can see the house now,
steady in its ... still silent.
They cannot speak. They use the biblical
prose. Old [Lacy tone?]
To Latimer, Robin Hood was a [illeg.] thief. He was
He had walked in the shadow of death " till he was 30,
but then his eyes were opened, & he was through
the cloud of superstition that still obscured his thought
He saw things as they were, he saw through the old
beliefs through the old Popish preachers, the old
pagan customs. He saw England still, at the moment
in its reality. He was no antiquary. He did
not dig in the garden for roman coins. When he
walked in the A of C Archbishop of Canterbury's garden, a man his man

came & said: "Sir there is one that
wd. would speak
with you." Then He shut his book, a heart He
he said so "the cry of the washerman is come up

The writer then must be a poet–– For
when familiar letters are written in –
To disengage the song from its encumberances
becomes as time goes on a task for the
critic – that specially qualified taster who
was not yet in existence when Spenser
emerged at last partially at least from
the depths of anonymity.
But he had the past behind him. For why a
For why a Gods name, he exclaimed may not we

p.l: So he was aware of his language, its possibilities, its
The writer must have the past behind him. For
Spenser the golden age was of English was Chaucer.
Behind him too is the Morte darthur
the old world of the Morte d'Arthur, the world is
Kings ladies, dwarfs, giants. But he has
ceased to believe in giants. Therefore
they have gone If He no longer believes, [unlike?]
noblemen in 1470 that King Arthur was a
real man. Thus his poem lacks the reality
of the Morte d'Arthur. It has not the He cannot
see within as Malory saw the: When MaloryMalory sees
sharply & distinctly, Spenser sees at a distance;
he sees with [regret?], with [illeg.] desire; but not
with belief. There is no sense of He cannot

p.l: There is no sharpness in the figures of the
Fairy Queen: no [vice?], no belief, no edge: no
such closeness or comes none of that

reality
wh. which comes from the belief: On the other
hand he shows us as Malory cannot, the
world surrounded by [words?]. His vision
is not fixed in the figure: but holds
the more so that if we lose the
He gives It holds the It holds the surrounding
[illeg.]. He realises time & change. And
again, he has the painters eye. Now like

the eye which gives the figures
wh. which [houses?]
them with the flower & the barbed thorn

There is no fear, but always [meriment?]. No

l.del: Still it is the world of

p.l: But still there is something anonymous about
Spenser. He must stand out cannot
confine his [characters?] in [huals?]: they are
symbolic. He externalises: he
embodies [learning?], not as a man, but gives it a
[separate?], a symbolic existence. Still The
He shall pass away ignores himself, the
first mind. The individual. He must
and at the same time, forces are at work
that are forcing the poet to be conscious of
himself, as a separate individual; a man
who he is giving something to the world: who
asks something: but w who is conscious of the
worlds scorn & neglect.
Then is the artist thus aware of his birth
as Chaucer was not, nor Langland, nor
Malory. He is becoming separate:
outside; Not all his [illeg.]
No longer a wandering voice, but specialised
He is indeed more When he
He was then the first self conscious poet.
The first real poet. And English poetry
might have continued to be a book read aloud
by the leisured in the great hall were had it
not been for the other voice – the voice at the
back door. Ironically [though?], when
Spenser himself heard the voice of the mummers. He

was present, it may be, at the pageant
wh. which
was acted before the Queen at Kenilworth.
He saw the players dressed in green.
He For time had made the peasant, probably
the Earth in his own [guise?], a spectacle, a
figure from the past. The old superstitions

were so [harmless?] that the
Q Queen was
awed at their survival. But even while
Spenser looked at their fantastic survival,
with his the stage was being
theatre was being built upon which
the old English was the mummers were to act
not Robin hood, not Gawain for the sophisticated
antiquated pageantry to the a sophisticated
